item.title: The Past As Present: Review
item.description: The implication of the past as present requires recognition of the integration of one with another, but also the distinctive difference in societies of earlier times and our times. Romilla Thapar discusses, in this book, how the past (many times imaginary) is invoked to give a force to a current political movement. She claims that history, especially ancient history, is not static, it changes as and when we develop a more in-depth understanding of archaeological evidence and their multidimensional understanding from the intersection of multiple disciples.
